item.detail_t: The beginning of the Web as a publicly available service on the Internet arrived on August 6, 1991, when Berners-Lee published the first-ever website. Fittingly, the site was about the World Wide Web project, describing the Web and how to use it. Hosted at CERN on Berners-Lee’s NeXT computer, the site’s URL was http://info.cern.ch.
item.detail_html: Greenwich was established as the universal time from which standard times throughout the world are calculated. British railway companies started introducing a single standard time across their networks, designed to make their timetables less confusing. In a congregation of 25 nations in Washington DC on this day, they decided to make Greenwich at 0 degrees latitude. Furthermore, this led to Greenwich being the international standard from where times would be calculated.
